title: Advertisement, "Westinghouse X-ray system", ca. 1960
medium: Offset lithograph on cream colored paper
signed: Imprinted in black ink, upper right quadrant: Paul Rand
inscribed: Imprinted in red ink, upper center: numbers 1-100; imprinted in black ink lower center in text block: Westinghouse/ x-ray system...can reduce/ radiation exposure/ 100 times; lower center in text block : A new Westinghouse X-ray television system gives the physician "instant replay."/ On pushbutton command, he can "freeze" a single frame of a continuing flouro-/ scopic study on a TV screen.  This enables him to study the internal body in detail; underneath this in text block: While the stored image is on, no X-ray exposure is needed to keep it displayed./Thus the patient's total exposure can be reduced by 10, 20  or as much as 100 times./ The system can also "tune out" bone structure and other images to give the phy-/ sycian the clearest possible TV picture of the internal organs; underneath this in text block: Helping sick people get better is a major activity at Westinghouse./ Making life brighter, cleaner and easier takes up the rest of our time./ You can be sure...if it's Westinghouse.
description: Cream colored ground; upper center, text block of numbers (1-100) imprinted in red ink; x-ray of person's chest in black and white superimposed on numbers.  Across lower center, four text blocks describe x-ray machine; lower right of text, Westinghouse logo.
